column4: after doing "aptitude update" on two different machines I get different versions of the same program on doing install. Why is that?
how can I check which version of a package is the latest in ubuntu?
What versions and of which program?
git-core, versions 1.4.4.4 and 1.4.4.2
Feisty has 1.4.4.2, not 1.4.4.4  do `apt-cache policy git-core` on the one with .4, see what repos it's using
one machine runs feisty, the other etch
ah!  Well, that's your disrepency.  One is using Ubuntu feisty, and the other one is using debian etch.
well according to the #git ppl both versions are ancient, how do I get up to speed?
I already have done "aptitude update" on both machines
Ubuntu freezes its versions of software (you stay with whatever version was released with feisty, except bugfixes), as does debian to some extent.  Thats why you don't have the latest versions.
You can either use feisty-backports, or upgrade to Gutsy
ohkay. isn't an upgrade likely to break a system that's heavily tweaked?
Depends on how heavily, but with no additional information, sure.  backports might be your best bet then.
what does "backports" mean exactly? That I run the latest version of one or two packages, but not the whole system?
how do I do that? (links to docs?)

yes.  People have taken the time to compile newer versions against the older libraries (in hardy).  Basically, the safest way is to manually odwnload the packages, and then install with gdebi.   http://packages.ubuntu.com/search?keywords=git&searchon=names&suite=feisty-backports&section=all
although, alternatively, you can add the -backports source to your sources, and do it that way as well.
would that force all packages to use backports, if I added it to sources?
Not force, but that is the danger of doing so (updating to backports packages without realising), which is why we don't recommend it.
gotcha. might be better off checking out the code in question directly from the git repos and building it from source.
thanx for the info though.
